title: PAX Association
text:
The PAX Association () was a pro-<a href="Communism">communist</a> <a href="Catholic%20Church">Catholic</a> organization created in 1947 in the <a href="People%27s%20Republic%20of%20Poland">People's Republic of Poland</a> at the onset of <a href="History%20of%20Poland%20%281945%E2%80%931989%29%23Stalinist%20era%20%281948%E2%80%931956%29">the Stalinist period</a>. The association published the "Słowo Powszechne" daily for almost fifty years between 1947 and 1993 with an average of 312 issues annually.
The first editor-in-chief of "Słowo Powszechne" (circulation: 40,000) was Wojciech Kętrzyński (d. 1983) from <a href="Konfederacja%20Narodu">KN</a>, grandson of historian <a href="Wojciech%20K%C4%99trzy%C5%84ski">Wojciech Kętrzyński</a>. In 1982 the newspaper adjusted its name to "Słowo Powszechne: dziennik Stowarzyszenia PAX" (the "PAX Association Daily"). The publication closed only when the PAX ceased to function in 1993, following the <a href="collapse%20of%20communism">collapse of communism</a>; however, the facsimile of the association was reestablished in 1993 under a different name: the Catholic association "<a href="Civitas%20Christiana">Civitas Christiana</a>".
Notably, in 1953 the PAX gave its support to the <a href="Stalinist%20show%20trial%20of%20the%20Krak%C3%B3w%20Curia">Stalinist show trial of the Kraków Curia</a> pronouncing death penalties for the Catholic priests accused of treason, and took over the publication of the Catholic weekly magazine "<a href="Tygodnik%20Powszechny">Tygodnik Powszechny</a>" until the <a href="Polish%20October">Polish October</a> of 1956.
Communist era.
Following the Soviet takeover, the PAX Association had been formed with the intention to undermine grass-roots support for the <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Church">Roman Catholic Church</a> in <a href="Stalinism%20in%20Poland">Stalinist Poland</a>. Created by <a href="Boles%C5%82aw%20Piasecki">Bolesław Piasecki</a>, it approved the trial and imprisonment of many Polish clergymen, among them <a href="Bishop">Bishop</a> <a href="Czes%C5%82aw%20Kaczmarek">Czesław Kaczmarek</a> and <a href="Cardinal%20%28Catholicism%29">Cardinal</a> <a href="Stefan%20Wyszy%C5%84ski">Stefan Wyszyński</a>. PAX attempted to compete with the conservative clergy of the interwar era over public policy issues, especially after the arrest of hundreds of priests by <a href="Ministry%20of%20Public%20Security%20%28Poland%29">the state security</a> in early 1950s. The government gave it total control over the Polish branch of the <a href="Caritas%20%28charity%29">Caritas</a> relief organisation. According to <a href="Norman%20Davies">Norman Davies</a> PAX was an <a href="NKVD">NKVD</a> front organisation, set up to win over Polish Catholics to communism, and to break their links to the Vatican. It maintained a presence in the <a href="Sejm">Sejm</a>, winning, for example, five seats in the <a href="1969%20Polish%20legislative%20election">1969 election</a>.
Reforms.
After 1956, together with many other similar government initiatives, it was toned down and took a more compromising position, in some regards even supporting the leniency for the <a href="Anti-communist%20resistance%20in%20Poland%20%281944%E2%80%931989%29">anti-communist resistance in Poland</a>, even though it firmly endorsed the communist government of the <a href="People%27s%20Republic%20of%20Poland">People's Republic of Poland</a> until the <a href="fall%20of%20communism">fall of communism</a>. After 1982 it was a member of the <a href="Patriotic%20Movement%20for%20National%20Rebirth">Patriotic Movement for National Rebirth</a>. Throughout the decades after its creation and the death of Stalin, it continued to steadily lose power and influence, although it still exists in modern Poland.
